awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Ultrasensitive frequency domain spectrometer for high throughput bacteria detection in floodwater
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Tufts University and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute to develop a frequency domain spectrometer for high throughput tracking of bacteria in flood water in real time.  In the aftermath of major catastrophic hurricanes like Harvey and Irma with winds that pull trees from their roots and roofs from houses, danger quietly continues at the microscopic level in the remaining floodwaters.  This EAGER research project will advance fundamental research on sensing technology for rapid characterization of pathogenic bacteria in floodwater generated by future catastrophic events.  Covering the spectrum from hybrid materials to system, there are variables and trade-offs that can only be clearly defined through methodical, directed experimentation. With this knowledge, synergistic innovations at material, device and system architecture are pursued to affect unprecedented sensor performance. The proposed cross-disciplinary research and education program will have significant broader impacts on fluorescence spectroscopy and optical sensor technology based on heterogeneous integration of nanocomposites on silicon.  Instrument miniaturization will enable new studies correlating factors in water quality. Interactive workshops with biochemists and students will be organized to guide spectrometer development. There is a strong mentoring and training component for students at all levels at Tufts, RPI and the broader community.

The objective of this proposal is to develop a highly sensitive frequency domain spectrometer instrument for high-throughput tracking of bacteria to quantify and identify bacteria in floodwater in real time, which significantly reduces labor, time, and cost.   The proposed work focuses on the spectral and temporal characteristics of intrinsic fluorescence and the material, device, and circuit innovations needed to detect them.    Significant technical barriers must be overcome including optical sensitivity, wavelength selectivity, environmental robustness, interference, low-noise signal amplification, and power consumption. The proposed instrument is built on enhancements from the synergistic properties of new nanocomposites that comprise an ultrasensitive device while remaining compatible with large-scale, silicon fabrication processes.  The proposed research work will benefit studies of pathogenic bacteria in floodwaters. The frequency domain spectrometer device is realized using a hybrid system-on-chip approach combining nanocomposite optoelectronic devices integrated with silicon CMOS technology for low-power, complex signal processing and bacteria classification.  Silicon integrated circuit technology enables system miniaturization, resulting in an overall reduction in power consumption and parasitic components that contribute to system noise and performance degradation. This project is well suited to an EAGER grant given the innovative aspects of the proposed research program involving the merger of self-assembled nanocomposite structures, high sensitivity analog electronics, ultra-low-power multiplexing and digitization circuitry, and emerging nanofabrication techniques. The project will realize a new class of portable fluorescence spectrometers, enabling high throughput spatial and temporal correlation of fluorescence emission data for bacteria characterization unachievable with current systems.  Motivated by the need to detect low level, RF-modulated optical signals over a wide dynamic range, this research project will explore the design of novel bipolar front-end analog circuitry with advanced features, including programmable gain, chopper stabilization, and offset compensation. Low-power circuit architectures for on-chip signal quantization and digitization will be explored to enable back-end digital processing for bacteria classification.

por.por_cntn:
The PIs leveraged their research from the NSF Lighting Enabled Systems and Applications (LESA) ERC Center to begin to meet the technological demands required to make a real-time, low power consuming, compact, robust, and ultrasensitive internet-of-microbial-sensors. In previous work, detecting microbes down to 7.81x10^7 cfu/100 ml was achieved in the open in ambient light (without being enclosed in a light-tight box) using frequency-modulated deep UV LEDs and an off-the-shelf silicon detector. Measuring in ambient light reduces the detection system's cost and complexity and adds to the streamlined design's robustness. Microbial detection approaches the order of 10 cfu/100 ml through the proposed work through combined innovations in the nanocomposite material, device, and system-on-a-chip integrated circuit design. Intrinsic fluorescence is the mechanism for optical analysis, where the internal properties of the microbes are probed by narrow, multi-wavelength excitation in the ultraviolet range. The resulting optical signature is collected by a system-on-chip platform consisting of an ultrasensitive detector array and advanced low-power, mixed-mode signal processing circuitry to extrapolate spectral and temporal properties. The proposed work covers the spectrum from hybrid materials to system, where variables and tradeoffs can only be clearly defined through methodical, directed experimentation. With this knowledge, synergistic innovations at material, device, and system architecture are pursued to affect unprecedented sensor performance. The results of this research enable its connection to a pre-existing sensor network and big data analysis, which can correlate harmful pathogens with other phenomena in disrupted ecosystems across the globe.

The exploitation of distinctive, synergistic electro-optical properties using nanocomposite materials for ultrasensitive detection was the primary objective. Thus, two approaches toward designing device structures that exploit inorganic/organic materials' unique characteristics to create unprecedented sensitivity to specific wavelengths of light while blocking unwanted wavelengths were pursued. A need to use simulation and modeling to shorten the time to explore essential tradeoffs experimentally led to the exploration and invention of a predictive model for metal oxide photodetectors to design high-gain and ultrasensitive ultraviolet detectors required for fluorescence-based bacteria sensing. Specifically, a limited understanding of oxygen adsorption and photodesorption at the surface of metal oxide nanomaterials hinders the rapid development of new hybrid material devices that depend on these phenomena for their ultrasensitive detection capabilities. The new model created for the adsorption process makes the analysis of metal-oxide photoconductors tractable. Secondly, the research led to experimental material and device fabrication needed to achieve the detection levels necessary to meet the requirements for a microbe sensor in the system-on-a-chip configuration with a pulsed light probe. The requirements are to create a visible blind, sub-microsecond response time, and >1000 A/W responsivity ultraviolet detector. Though a hybrid ZnO quantum dot-graphene phototransistor device based on previous work was further investigated, the research led to hybrid perovskite-based devices. With the new adsorption model as a foundation of predictive simulation of metal oxide-based device performance, the hybrid ZnO quantum phototransistor will be precisely tuned to optimize its high-gain and fast-time response potential in future work.  The perovskite-based devices met these requirements without need of these optimzation steps. In associated research, one example of the perovskite-based device includes the novel wide-bandgap vacancy-ordered lead-free inorganic perovskite Cs2SnCl6 with Nd3+ doping, employed in the active layer of a hybrid photodetector.  Remarkably, with interfacial charge controlled hole-injection operating mechanism, our device achieves a maximum detectivity of 6.3x10^15 jones at 372 nm, a large linear dynamic range of 118 dB and a fast photoresponse speed (~2.5 us rise time and ~1.8 us fall time). A maximum photoresponsivity of 2103 A/W and EQE of 7.01x10^5% are achieved at the wavelength of 372 nm (3.3 eV). The performance is significantly better than most of the existing organic and inorganic semiconductor UV photodetectors reported so far, and its detectivity is closing to one order of magnitude higher than that of the photo-multiplier tube (PMT) in the UV region. In addition, the photodetector demonstrated excellent environmental stability, which is critical for commercial deployment of perovskite based optoelectronic devices.
